awd_titl_txt: Regulation of dual nitrogenases in response to nitrogen stress in a cyanobacterium
awd_abstract_narration:
Cyanobacteria are ancient microorganisms that were among the first organisms to produce oxygen on earth. Today, cyanobacteria are important organisms in the environment. They get their energy from sunlight, their carbon from carbon dioxide in the air, and their nitrogen from the nitrogen gas in the air. They are important not only as free-living organisms, but also as partners in many symbiotic associations with plants and fungi. The cyanobacterium Anabaena can use the energy from sunlight to convert nitrogen gas in the air to ammonia. This process is called nitrogen fixation. In contrast, chemical production of fertilizer requires large amounts of fossil fuels and produces greenhouse gases. The project will investigate the regulation of nitrogen fixation in Anabaena, one of the best characterized cyanobacteria in terms of growth, physiology and genetics. A second key objective of this project is to involve, educate, and support diverse students as members of the research team. This project will include high school students, especially from underserved school districts, undergraduates and graduate students, working together as active participants in the research.

Anabaena is unique in model cyanobacterial systems in that it has two homologous nitrogenase systems. One functions only in specialized anaerobic cells called heterocysts under aerobic growth condition, while the other functions only in anaerobically-grown vegetative cells. This research will determine the mechanisms that control expression of these complementary nitrogenases, focusing on global mechanisms that respond to nitrogen stress. This project will characterize the two primary activator proteins, CnfR1 and CnfR2, which lead to differential expression of the two nitrogenase gene clusters in heterocysts or vegetative cells. Further, the research will determine, at a system-wide level, the role of known global stress factors and transcription factors, in regulation of the two nitrogenase systems. Taking a synthetic biology approach, nitrogenase genes from Anabaena will be expressed in a strain that lacks this capability, as part of the longer term goal of producing a "nitroplast", a hypothetical cyanobacterial-like organelle in a plant cell that could fix nitrogen for the plant. The goal of moving nitrogenase genes to plants is to reduce reliance on nitrogen-containing fertilizers for crop production. These objectives will be achieved by combining traditional genetic techniques with synthetic biology approaches.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Anabaena variabilis is a photosynthetic microorganism called a cyanobacterium, which is essentially a simple plant. However, unlike most plants, the organism grows in chain-like filaments of blue-green cells. Its growth, physiology, and genetics are well characterized; thus, it serves as a model biological system. It grows well with fixed nitrogen, which is similar to plant fertilizer, but it can also grow without fixed nitrogen by a process called nitrogen fixation. Nitrogen fixation converts atmospheric nitrogen (80% of air) to ammonia in specialized cells called heterocysts in Anabaena, using the enzyme nitrogenase. In cyanobacteria, nitrogen fixation 1) contributes substantially to the global nitrogen cycle, particularly through nitrogen fixation in the oceans; 2) provides fixed nitrogen to many plants through symbiosis; and 4) provides a genetically useful, photosynthetic system for studies that may eventually lead to the bioengineering of a ?nitroplast? that can fix nitrogen in a plant cell.

 

The regulation by cyanobacteria of heterocyst formation, nitrogen fixation, and symbiosis with plants is poorly understood. Nitrogen fixation is a very expensive process for cells and uses a large amount of energy; hence, it is tightly regulated. In this research, we have characterized key regulators that control the expression of two independent nitrogen fixation gene clusters, nif1 and nif2, in Anabaena. The nif1 nitrogenase is expressed only in the specialized cells called heterocysts, while the nif2 nitrogenase is expressed in vegetative cells, but only in the absence of oxygen, which poisons nitrogenase. One important outcome of this research is that nif1 gene expression is controlled by a protein called CnfR1, whereas nif2 gene expression is controlled by a related but distinct protein called CnfR2. This is consistent with our prior research that demonstrated that the regulation of nif1 and nif2 gene clusters has been highly conserved throughout evolution. CnfR1 and CnfR2 are critical for normal nitrogenase expression and thus for nitrogen fixation in response to the appropriate environmental signals. Consistent with its role in activating nif1 expression, CnfR1 is made only in heterocysts, and CnfR2 is made only in vegetative cells lacking oxygen. These two independent regulators ensure that the nif1 and nif2 genes are expressed only when they are needed under the correct environmental conditions to support nitrogen fixation. Future research to attempt to transfer the nif2 nitrogenase to a plant cell to create a nitrogen-fixing plant cell requires an in-depth understanding of gene regulation of the nif genes. This research has greatly advanced our knowledge of nif gene regulation in cyanobacteria.  

 

In addition to the new scientific knowledge produced by this research, this award supported the research of high school students, undergraduate students, graduate students, and a technician. Further, a group of undergraduate students engaged in collaborative research on cyanobacterial nitrogen fixation in an Undergraduate Research Course. The research from one of these classes led to a 2021 publication on the characterization of the genomes of 10 cyanobacteria isolated from a symbiotic association with a water fern called Azolla. Many of these undergraduate students continued to work on independent research projects for at least a year after the end of the course, and several students pursued graduate degrees as a result of their knowledge and interest in research. The University of Missouri-St. Louis developed a partnership program with several school districts that have a high proportion of minority students called CLIMB (Collaborative Laboratory Internship and Mentoring Blueprint) to engage students interested in STEM disciplines. Our lab hosted several of these summer high school students to stimulate their interest in science and to help them to make a successful transition to college.
